Description: This Paths of the trail is the most southern; here you go through dessert
Description_new: This southernmost trail section crosses desert terrain. Stay hydrated as temperatures fluctuate dramatically between day and night. The path winds alongside Sheephead Mountain and Wooden Hill; partially through Sawtooth Mountains wilderness; featuring characteristic mountain formations.

Description: You are in the very southern part and in summer this can be very hot
Description_new: Located in the southern region; this segment can be extremely hot in summer. You'll traverse Anza-Borrego Desert State Park; notable for spring wildflower blooms. Established in 1932; the park is named after explorer Juan Bautista de Anza and "borrego;" Spanish for sheep. The park spans 237;120 hectares.

Description: You will pass through rugged desert terrain featuring occasional oases and challenging climbs in this segment
Description_new: This segment features rugged desert terrain with occasional oases and challenging climbs. Passing Warner Springs; a set of natural springs and small community in northern San Diego County; you'll hike near Combs Peak. Recent fires on eastern flanks have made the approach from PCT easier through typical chaparral country with manzanita; scrub oak; and buckthorn.

Description: You will walk through Jacinto Wildernes
Description_new: You'll traverse Jacinto Wilderness; passing near Suicide Rock; which offers excellent views without climbing major peaks. The Deer Springs Trail ascends through oak and pine forests to a massive granite slab with panoramic mountain vistas. A free permit is required for hiking to Suicide Rock.

Description: You need to cross Mission Creek several times
Description_new: You'll have views of Sand to Snow National Monument featuring iconic red mountains backed by snow-covered peaks. The trail also leads up Onyx Peak; a mountain pass located in the southwestern San Bernardino Mountains.

Description: On this part of the Trail yo can see Mt Baden Powell who is the founder of scouts. The first groups of scouts were formed in 1907 on the basis og his book Aids for Scouting
Description_new: This segment offers views of Big Bear Lake; the jewel of San Bernardino National Forest; known for fishing; winter sports; hiking; and mountain biking. You'll walk through San Bernardino National Forest; covering 3;333.87 km_ divided into northern and southern portions. The area served as filming locations for Daniel Boone (1936) and Paint Your Wagon (1969).

Description: You walk on the egde of Big Bear City
Description_new: You'll cross Interstate 15 and climb 1;436 meters in a long stretch; passing Table Mountain and Mount San Antonio. Nearby Vasquez Rock features striking jagged formations created by millions of years of rapid erosion; serving as a popular filming location for movies and TV shows.

Description: You go in Angeles National forests
Description_new: You'll hike through Angeles National Forest; an urban wilderness providing solitude and unique recreation opportunities for surrounding communities. The trail includes climbing Mt. Baden Powell; named after the founder of scouts who formed the first groups in 1907. Baden-Powell is a classic San Gabriel peak-bagging must-do.

Description: On this part of the route you walk in a mixture of hilly terrain and valleys of sand You are both  on the egde of moutains and have some of the trail in the city of Lancaster
Description_new: This segment traverses hilly terrain and sandy valleys; passing through Agua Dulce; a charming rural community covering 59 square kilometers; known for rolling hills and country lifestyle. Near Lancaster; you'll encounter Walker's Pass and Burnt Peak (1;781m); which offers expansive views; while Lake Hughes provides tranquil waters for leisure activities.

Location: Sierra Nevada & Northern California - Kennedy Meadows
Description: This part of the trail is hilly and you will need to cross several small creeks
Description_new: This hilly section requires crossing several small creeks. You'll see Double Mountain with its two similarly elevated summits south of Tehachapi. The route passes near Mojave; a desert city established in 1876 as a Southern Pacific Railroad construction camp that later served as the western terminus for twenty-mule teams from Death Valley.

Location: Sierra Nevada & Northern California - Sequoia National Park
Description: You will both walk in hilly terran and forretes
Description_new: This section begins with an ascent of Welden Peak offering expansive views. The trail winds between Piute Peak and Sorrell Peak showcasing diverse vegetation and geological features; then skirts Pinyon Mountain where alpine landscapes blend with dense pinyon pine forests.

Location: Sierra Nevada & Northern California - Forester Pass
Description: You walk in both Owen Peak Wilderness; Kiavah Wildernes and Domeland Wildernes. A part with a lot of protected nature; so in this path the chance for uniqe experince
Description_new: The trail traverses three wilderness areas: Owens Peak; Kiavah; and Domeland. Starting at Weldon Peak; it continues between Piute Peak and Sorrell Peak; then skirts Pinyon Mountain to the distinctive Sawtooth Peak. Each wilderness offers unique landscapes from rugged terrain to intricate rock formations and forested areas rich in biodiversity.

Location: Sierra Nevada & Northern California - Kings Canyon National Park
Description: You will be climbing many meters both up and down. You will be walking through the South Sierra Wilderness and there will be several mountain peaks and peaks around you along the way
Description_new: This immersive section through South Sierra Wilderness is surrounded by dramatic peaks including Rockhouse; Ball Mountain; Bald Mountain; and Olancha Peak. The trail winds through diverse terrains with each peak providing a unique backdrop. The remote beauty offers profound connections with nature amid towering mountains and serene wilderness.

Location: Sierra Nevada & Northern California - Tuolumne Meadows
Description: You are walking in an area with many mountains. Some of the ones you can see on the trip are: Mount Withney; Mount Langley; Kern Peak; Cirque Peak
Description_new: The path traverses breathtaking landscapes dominated by Sierra Nevada's highest peaks. From north to south; you encounter Mount Stanford and Mount Williamson; towering over the trail with challenging climbs and rewarding views. The trail continues toward iconic Mount Whitney; then descends slightly toward Mount Langley and Cirque Peak before culminating near Muah Mountain.

Location: Sierra Nevada & Northern California - Sonora Pass
Description: You are in the middel of Inyo National Forrest. Inyo National Forest extends approximately 265 kilometers near the California and Nevada border. It covers about 809.371 hectares mostly on the eastern slope of the Sierra Nevada
Description_new: Located in Inyo National Forest; which extends 265 kilometers near the California-Nevada border covering 809;371 hectares on the Sierra Nevada's eastern slope. The trail passes between Mount Clarence King; Acrodectes Peak; Mount Goddard; and Mount Darwin - -a flat-topped 4;218-meter peak on the border of Fresno and Inyo counties.

Location: Sierra Nevada & Northern California - Lake Tahoe
Description: You are walking in an area with many mountains and you encounter many altitude differences at the same time there are many larger and smaller lakes
Description_new: This Sierra Nevada segment features dramatic altitude changes around peaks like Bloody Mountain; Red Slate Mountain; Mount Morgan; Bear Creek Spire; and Seven Gables. Various lakes near Silver Peak and Mammoth Lakes offer serene vistas. The trail combines high peaks and water bodies creating a dynamic hiking experience with photography and wildlife observation opportunities.

Location: Sierra Nevada & Northern California - Donner Memorial State Park
Description: You walk in both Ansel Adams Wildernes and the great Yosemite National Park. It was first protected in 1864.Yosemite National Park is best known for its waterfalls but you can find deep valleys and grand meadows as well
Description_new: Traverse the Ansel Adams Wilderness and Yosemite National Park; experiencing pristine alpine scenery with peaks like Mount Ritter and Mount Lyell before entering Yosemite; known for biodiversity; waterfalls; valleys; meadows; and sequoias. Key landmarks include Mount Dana and Clouds Rest offering expansive views; connecting you with American wilderness conservation history.

Location: Sierra Nevada & Northern California - Feather River
Description: As the trail moves northward; it traverses the lush forests of Northern California; with a mix of steep inclines and dense woodland  During this par of the trail You'll cross the border between California and Oregon
Description_new: The trail navigates through the northern Yosemite Wilderness and Hoover Wilderness with lush forests and challenging terrain. It passes through Tower Peak; offering deep backcountry experiences with physically demanding journeys through the Carson-Iceberg Wilderness. Notable landmarks include Highland Peak; Whitecliff Peak; Sonora Peak; and Leavitt Peak; featuring rugged terrain and glacial remnants.

Description: It is a varied terrain with both forest and desert  and you will pass by a lot of large and small lakes
Description_new: The Lake Tahoe trail offers a captivating journey through majestic landscapes in the Lake Tahoe Basin Management Unit. It ascends towards Ralston Peak and Pyramid Peak providing sweeping views of the lake and dense forests. This breathtaking section attracts both seasoned hikers and scenic experience seekers; with unique recreational opportunities nearby.

Description: You will walk in Donner Memorial State Park some of the parth. The very large Lake Tahoe is close by  the closest towns to the trail are Tahoe Pines; Homewood and Rubicon Bay
Description_new: This segment near Lake Tahoe weaves through rugged terrain with scenic forest and mountain views. Notable peaks include Granite Chief and Tinker Knob; part of the Tahoe Rim Trail. The nearby towns of Truckee and Tahoe City offer amenities; historical charm; and services for resupply and relaxation; blending wilderness hiking with community access.

Description: You walk on the egde opf Sierra city. You need to cross North Yuba River and Haypress Creek. When Crossing North Yba Falls You walk very close to Love Falls
Description_new: The path crosses North Yuba River and Haypress Creek; featuring beautiful natural water formations. Near the North Yuba River crossing; you'll come close to North Yuba Falls and Love Falls; popular spots for their picturesque views and cascading water sounds. The proximity to Sierra City provides civilization before returning to secluded Tahoe National Forest paths.

Description: This is a hilly stretch where you also have to cross the Middle Fork Feather River
Description_new: This section traverses Plumas National Forest through dense forests; mountainous vistas; and remote wilderness. Surrounded by Northern Sierra Nevada's natural beauty; the isolated trail offers peaceful solitude and rich biodiversity. Nearby Quincy provides a convenient resupply point before continuing through expansive wilderness ideal for immersion in the Sierra Nevada's less-traveled paths.

Description: If You do the hole trail you are in this segment in the middel or half to reach your desination. You need to cross North Fork Feather River and Yellow Creek
Description_new: Marking the midpoint for thru-hikers; this section traverses Bucks Lake Wilderness with prominent features like Bald Eagle Mountain; Ben Lomond; and Snow Mountain. The trail crosses Highway 70 multiple times providing access points. Hikers enjoy diverse landscapes including forests; rocky outcrops at Castle and Eagle Rocks; and wildlife viewing in less frequented areas.

Description: You will here walk in Lassen Volcanic National Park. You walk between different Mountans and Peaks. This is a parth with various elevation
Description_new: Navigate diverse volcanic landscapes featuring Lassen Peak; one of the world's largest plug dome volcanoes; alongside Brokeoff Mountain and Mount Harkness. The path winds through mixed forests; mountain streams; and meadows providing varied ecosystems and wildlife viewing opportunities. Volcanic landmarks and natural beauty enrich the hiking experience with physical challenges.

Description: You will cross Pit River and come close to Burney Falls; which is 25 meter and defenitly a visit worth. Here You can find campsites and Rental Cabins
Description_new: The trail offers rolling hills; dense forests; and meadows with a river crossing adding dynamic elements. Near Pit River; hikers enjoy stunning views and wildlife habitats contrasting with surrounding dry terrain. The trail passes near Burney Mountain for dramatic views and challenging hiking; with Burney nearby for convenient resupply before continuing through serene paths.

Description: You'll walk in Shasta-Trinity National Forrest and Lassen National Forrest. If the water level is high You need to cross several small creeks and streams
Description_new: The path traverses rugged mountainous terrain marked by Grizzly Peak; Brushy Butte; and Tamarack Mountain; offering panoramic views and wilderness immersion. Characterized by steep climbs and descents testing hiker endurance across varied elevations; the landscape features dense forests and occasional clearings providing scenic vistas and wildlife observation opportunities.

Location: Oregon - Bridge of the Gods (Columbia River Gorge)
Description: You'll walk through Castle Crags Wilderness and Castle Crags State Park. You will cross Burstarse Creek; Indidan Creek and Popcorn Spring during the trail  You will be able to see several peaks on this parth including: Russian Peak; Deadman Peak; Eagle Peak; Sugar Hill; Craggy Peak; Cory Peak and Mount Eddy
Description_new: Traverse Castle Crags Wilderness and State Park; crossing Burstarse Creek; Indian Creek; and Popcorn Spring. The Sacramento River crossing near Dunsmuir is significant. Peaks include Russian Peak; Deadman Peak; Eagle Peak; Sugar Hill; Craggy Peak; Cory Peak; and Mount Eddy. Shasta-Trinity National Forest; California's largest; offers diverse ecosystems from alpine forests to wildflower meadows.

Description: You will walk in Klamath National forres and Marble Mountain Wilderness. You climpe Big Ridge with the elevation of 2141meters
Description_new: This segment traverses the expansive rugged terrains of Klamath National Forest and Marble Mountain Wilderness; known for dramatic landscapes. You'll climb Big Ridge at 2;141 meters elevation.

Description: On this stretch you will pass through Seaid Wally and up over Kangaroo Mountain; Black Mountain and Observation Peak among others. A stretch with many meters of elevation gain
Description_new: Passing through Seiad Valley; the trail climbs Kangaroo Mountain; Black Mountain; and Observation Peak with significant elevation gain rewarded by breathtaking views. The route winds through remote areas between mountains for an immersive wilderness experience across diverse landscapes from forests to rocky outcrops. Seiad Valley offers a resupply checkpoint along the Klamath River.

Description: During this par of the trail You'll cross the border between California and Oregon
Description_new: This impressive section through Carson-Iceberg Wilderness features Highland Peak; Whitecliff Peak; Sonora Peak; and Leavitt Peak. The stretch showcases rugged terrain; dramatic elevations; and the Sierra's eastern slope beauty. The wilderness is known for rocky landscapes; glacial remnants; geological formations; dense conifer forests; and waterways; with peaks offering spectacular high-altitude views.

Description: You will walk in The Sky Lakes Wilderness straddles southern Oregon's Cascade Range from Crater Lake National Park southward to Oregon Route 140. It is approximately 9.7 kmwide and 43 km long. Thelevations ranging from 1.200 m in the canyon of the Middle Fork of the Rogue River to 2.894 m at the top of Mount McLoughlin is the highest peak in southern Oregon
Description_new: Sky Lakes Wilderness straddles Oregon's Cascade Range from Crater Lake National Park to Oregon Route 140; spanning approximately 9.7 km wide and 43 km long. Elevations range from 1;200 m at Middle Fork Rogue River to 2;894 m at Mount McLoughlin; southern Oregon's highest peak.

Description: You will walk close by Crater Lake that is surrounded by several high points. This including Garfield Peak; Llao Rock and Grouse Hill
Description_new: Walk near Crater Lake surrounded by Garfield Peak; Llao Rock; and Grouse Hill within Crater Lake National Park. Formed 7;700 years ago when a violent eruption collapsed a tall peak; the lake is America's deepest and one of Earth's most pristine. Established in 1902; it's Oregon's only national park and the fifth-oldest in the US.

Description: On this part You walk in hilly terrain and pass Cowhorn Mountain which is  2336 meters high
Description_new: Offering serene hiking through expansive views; lush forests; and Diamond Peak's rugged slopes; this section passes Cowhorn Mountain (2;336 meters). The trail also skirts several lakes providing water sources and scenic camping spots ideal for relaxation.

Description: In this Segment You will walk through Willamette National Forrest and Deschutes National Forrest and pass several lakes
Description_new: This segment traverses Oregon's volcanic landscape passing the iconic Three Sisters volcanoes. Hikers gain close-up views of North; Middle; and South Sister while The Husband stands opposite; creating a dramatic skyline. The Three Sisters Wilderness offers diverse ecosystems including alpine forests; lava fields; and wildflower meadows; making this a memorable PCT section.

Description: On this part of the trail You walk past tree vulcanos that is caled The Tree Sisters. When You have Middel Sister and South sister on one side You will have the moutan The husband on the other side of you
Description_new: Traverse Mount Jefferson and Mount Washington Wildernesses; known for rugged terrain and volcanic features. Mount Washington; with its distinctive spire-like top; stands out in this less crowded area offering solitude. The trail combines steep rocky ascents and serene forest walks with wildlife viewing and panoramic Cascade Range vistas; delivering a classic Pacific Northwest experience.

Description: On this part of the trial You will wlak in the National Park of Mount Hood  Mount Hood is also known as Wy'east. It is an active stratovolcano. The summit elavation is 3.429 meter and has glaciers all year
Description_new: Passing through Oregon's Clackamas Wilderness near Mount Hood (Wy'east) - -an active 3;429m stratovolcano with year-round glaciers. The trail skirts Olallie Butte overlooking numerous lakes and forests near Mount Jefferson. Mount Hood Wilderness; designated in 1964; offers pristine landscapes with alpine meadows; streams; and old-growth forests; renowned for hiking; backpacking; and climbing opportunities.

Location: Northern Washington & Canada Border - Pasayten Wilderness
Description: On this part You'll cross the Columbia River and also the border between Oregon and Washinton. On both sides You walk in forrest. This could be a good place to stock up as you come right through the town of Casade Locks which is the biggest city You will go through
Description_new: Cross the Columbia River and Oregon-Washington border through forests. Cascade Locks; the largest town on the trail; provides an excellent resupply opportunity.

Location: Northern Washington & Canada Border - Holman Pass
Description: Now You are walkning in Gifford Pinoct National Forrest. It contains over 1.3 milion acers of green forests soaring mountains; dewy meadows; and rapid streams
Description_new: The trail meanders through Indian Heaven Wilderness with old-growth forests; alpine lakes; and vibrant wildflower meadows. Diverse landscapes and changing elevations challenge and reward hikers as they pass Sawtooth Mountain; Bird Mountain; and Lemel Rock; offering wildlife observation opportunities. The area is especially known for brilliant autumn foliage colors.

Location: Northern Washington & Canada Border - Windy Pass
Description: On this part You walk through the Mount Adams Wildersness; where the trail take you close to the mountan and the glacier
Description_new: Traverse Mount Adams Wilderness near the mountain and glacier; then through Goat Rocks Wilderness past Gilbert Peak (2;494m) - -the highest summit in the Goat Rocks; which are eroded remnants of an extinct stratovolcano. Meade Glacier lies on southeastern slopes while Conrad Glacier is on the north slope.

Location: Northern Washington & Canada Border - Castle Pass
Description: Mount Rainier is the most glaciated peak in the contiguous U.S.A.; spawning five major rivers. You will see subalpine wildflower meadows ring the icy volcano while ancient forest cloaks Mount Rainiers lower slopes
Description_new: Journey through William O. Douglas and Norse Peak Wilderness areas near Mount Rainier; America's most glaciated contiguous peak. Experience diverse ecosystems with subalpine wildflower meadows against stark white glaciers and ancient forests. The trail passes Norse Peak; Crown Point; and Pigtail Peak; each offering unique Mount Rainier vistas.

Location: Northern Washington & Canada Border - Monument 78 (Canada Border)
Description: You are walking in Norse Peak Wildernes
Description_new: Visit Kelly Butte Lookout (1;640m) for panoramic Central Cascades views. Built in the 1920s and reconstructed in the 1950s; it overlooks surrounding forests and distant peaks. Pass through Snoqualmie Pass (919m); an important mountain gateway 50 miles east of Seattle carrying Interstate 90 across the Cascades.

Location: Northern Washington & Canada Border - Manning Park (Canada)
Description: You go thrugh Snoqualmie is best known as the home of Snoqualmie Falls- a breathtaking waterfall cascading 81.6 meter over granite cliffs. Snoqualmie Falls is the second most visited natural landmark in Washington after Mount Rainier. It is more than twice as high as Niagara Falls!
Description_new: Traverse the Alpine Lakes Wilderness with rugged terrain; deep valleys; craggy peaks; and numerous alpine lakes. Key features include challenging climbs and scenic Chimney Rock. The Henry M. Jackson Wilderness (41;803 ha); created by the 1984 Washington Wilderness Act; features steep slopes and finger ridges with streams draining into the Sauk and Skykomish Rivers.

Description: You are walking in Alpine Lake Wildernes
Description_new: This segment passes Mount David; a prominent 2;260-meter summit in Chelan County within Glacier Peak Wilderness on Okanogan-Wenatchee National Forest land.

Location: Northern Washington & Canada Border - Hope - British Columbia
Description: You are walking in the north and meeting several glaciers including Kennedy Peak and Glacier Peak
Description_new: Encounter Kennedy Peak and Glacier Peak (3;213m); Washington's fourth highest peak featuring several glaciers including White Chuck; Kennedy; and Suiattle. Surrounding Glacier Peak Wilderness spans approximately 229;075 ha; designated in 1964; known for steep rugged terrain; old-growth forests; and alpine lakes protecting the Sauk; Suiattle; and White Chuck Rivers with minimal human disturbance.

Location: Northern Washington & Canada Border - Fraser Valley
Description: In theese segments the trail cover some of the most challenging and rewarding terrain of the PCT; culminating in the alpine glory of the North Cascades  This is the most northly part of the trail
Description_new: This northernmost section features high alpine peaks and remote wilderness near Bonanza Peak; Mount Fernow; and Lake Chelan National Recreation Area. Significant elevation changes near Goode Mountain and Black Peak provide dramatic vistas. Mount Winthrop (2;393m) is visible before reaching the Northern Terminus at the US-Canada border near Manning Park; marked by a wooden monument.
